questions.question: What is the analogy we used to explain disease spread?
options: Sharing lunch
Gossip in school
Tag
Wearing masks

questions.question: What tools can we use to simulate gossip spreading?
options: Dice and coins
Rulers
Stones
Maps

questions.question: What happens if each infected person spreads a disease to just a few more people?
options: The disease slowly disappears
The disease spreads faster and faster
No matter what, everyone will get infected
The disease is guaranteed to stop after a few days
questions.correct: The disease spreads faster and faster

questions.question: Why is flipping a coin a good analogy for how a disease spreads?
options: We don't know what the exact outcome of each coin-flip will be but we can still make predictions, infections work the same way
Every person always spreads the disease to exactly two other people, like two sides of a coin
Diseases only spread when people are playing games with coins
The number of times a coin lands on heads tells us how long the disease lasts
questions.correct: We don't know what the exact outcome of each coin-flip will be but we can still make predictions, infections work the same way

questions.question: What are some goals of visualization?
options: To create awareness and understanding
To create awareness by inducing fear
To make data more machine processable and readable
To confuse people

questions.question: What is the distance between the two highlighted marks on this scale?
According to this line plot, what was the temperature at hour 12?
What hour and temperature does the highlighted point represent?
options: temperature: 18, hour: 3
temperature: 3, hour: 18
temperature: 7, hour: 18
temperature: 6, hour: 0

questions.question: What is the node marked with the red dashed circle called?
options: root node
main node
top node
start node

questions.question: What is the distance between the nodes 2 and 11?
What is the depth of this tree?
Why can it be useful to model the expected number of new infections in a day?
options: To prepare hospitals for potential new patients
To stop a disease from spreading
To develop cures for new diseases
To reduce the number of daily infections
questions.correct: To prepare hospitals for potential new patients

questions.question: What do S, I and R mean in the SIR model?
options: S = Susceptible, I = Infectious, R = Recovered
S = Sick, I = Immune, R = Removed
S = Susceptible, I = Immune, R = Resistant
S = Sick, I = Infectious, R = Recovered
questions.correct: S = Susceptible, I = Infectious, R = Recovered

questions.question: What is the transmission rate?
options: How many people one sick person infects a day on average
The rate at which people recover from the disease
The speed of people moving between each compartment
The initial number of infected people
questions.correct: How many people one sick person infects a day on average

questions.question: We got this plot using the SIR model to model the spread of gossip, using only the S and I compartments. We started the simulation with one person knowing about the gossip and a total of 12 people. Which of the lines shows the total number of people in the S compartment, and which shows the total number of people in the I compartment?
options: The blue continuous line is S, and the orange dashed line is I
The blue continuous line is I, and the orange dashed line is R
None of the alternatives is correct
Both lines represent the S compartment
questions.correct: The blue continuous line is S, and the orange dashed line is I

questions.question: Let's say that we would like to model the spread of a disease in a school with 300 people. On the first day, 4 people were infected and started spreading the disease, and one person had already recovered from the disease. How should you set the number of people in each compartment?
Test question
Why could we need a different model instead of the SIR model?
options: Because the SIR model cannot consider differences between individuals
Because the SIR model takes too long to calculate for large populations
Because the SIR model always predicts the exact number of sick people
Because the SIR model requires expensive simulations to run
questions.correct: Because the SIR model cannot consider differences between individuals

questions.question: What is an 'agent' in agent based models?
options: A group of people who are treated as if they are all the same
A single individual with their own characteristics and rules
A mathematical equation that predicts the spread of disease
A random event like a coin flip
questions.correct: A single individual with their own characteristics and rules

questions.question: In an agent-based model, what makes an agent different from the 'beads' in the SIR analogy?
options: Agents can have different characteristics and behaviors
Agents cannot change state once they are infected
Agents all behave exactly the same way
Agents are used only for very large populations
questions.correct: Agents can have different characteristics and behaviors

questions.question: What is the 'legend' of a plot?
options: There is no such thing
A story told by the plot
An explanation of what each line in the plot represents
A story that is based on a plot
questions.correct: An explanation of what each line in the plot represents

questions.question: What is important to be considered when adding multiple lines to the same plot?
options: You shouldn't add more than 3 lines
The lines should have similar scales
You shouldn't add multiple lines to a plot
Adding multiple lines is hard
questions.correct: The lines should have similar scales

questions.question: What are the transitions called in our extended SIR model example?
options: a: vaccination rate, b: transmission rate, c: recovery rate
a: transmission rate, b: vaccination rate, c: recovery rate
a: vaccination rate, b: recovery rate, c: transmission rate
a: recovery rate, b: transmission rate, c: vaccination rate
questions.correct: a: vaccination rate, b: transmission rate, c: recovery rate

questions.question: Why is it that it is not always simpler to 'just use more data' than extending our base SIR model?
options: Because we don't always have more data
Because we would have no way to visualize all the data
Because the computer can't process lots of numbers
Because we can't always use all the data we have
questions.correct: Because we don't always have more data

questions.question: Placeholder question (correct: 1)
